edu.illinois.cs.cs125.spring2019.mp0.lib

Class Locator

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.illinois.cs.cs125.spring2019.mp0.lib.Locator

  • public class Locator
extends java.lang.Object
    A class that runs implements several helper functions on location data. You are expected to understand and complete the functions as declared and described below.
    See Also:
    MP0 Documentation

    • Method Detail

      • farthestNorth

        public static int farthestNorth(double[] latitudes,
                                double[] longitudes,
                                boolean[] validLocations)
        Determine which of a set of positions is the furthest north.

        The passed arrays contain latitude and longitude measurements, with each index storing one of a pair of measurements, along with an array of booleans indicating which measurements are valid. So, for example, latitude[0] and longitudes[0] comprise one location measurement. If validLocations[0] is true the location is valid, otherwise it is not.

        Note that you must return the index of the valid measurement that is furthest north, not the value itself. If multiple valid locations are equally far north you should return the index of the first one in the arrays. If the array contains no valid locations you should return -1.

        This method is used by the MP0 location app to place a special pin on the map in the location that is the furthest north. Will you make it all the way to a visit with Santa?

        Parameters:
        latitudes - array of previous latitude measurements
        longitudes - array of previous longitude measurements
        validLocations - the array containing whether the location at an index is valid or not
        Returns:
        the index in the array containing the position that is furthest north.

      • beenHere

        public static boolean beenHere(int currentIndex,
                               double[] latitudes,
                               double[] longitudes,
                               boolean[] validLocations)
        Determine whether you've already been in this exact spot.

        This function is passed the index of the current location along with arrays of latitude and longitude values, and an array that indicates whether the location at an index is valid or not. (When the app starts up the location arrays are initially filled with invalid measurements.)

        Parameters:
        currentIndex - the index of the current location to compare against
        latitudes - the array containing previous latitude measurements
        longitudes - the array containing previous longitude measurements
        validLocations - the array containing whether the location at an index is valid or not
        Returns:
        true if the array contains another valid location equal to the current one

      • nextRandomLocation

        public static double[] nextRandomLocation(double currentLatitude,
                                          double currentLongitude,
                                          double transitionProbability,
                                          double latitudeChange,
                                          double longitudeChange)
        Generate a new random location based on the current position and a transition probability.

        This function is passed the latitude and longitude of the current position and a transition probability. With probability equal to the passed value you should modify the latitude and longitude by the passed parameters. In other cases you should not modify the latitude and longitude.

        You should return an array of doubles of size 2 with the first index equal to the returned latitude and the second equal to the returned longitude.

        Also note that you should ensure that the values that you return are valid using the constants defined above. If a change would cause a location value to become invalid, you should correct it so that it is valid. For example, a latitude of 89.0 cannot be increased by 2.0, since 91.0 is not a valid latitude. In that case you should return 90.0, the result bounded to within the valid range.

        Parameters:
        currentLatitude - the current latitude to possibly modify
        currentLongitude - the current longitude to possibly modify
        transitionProbability - the probability that the latitude and longitude will change
        latitudeChange - the amount to change the latitude if it changes
        longitudeChange - the amount to change the longitude if it changes
        Returns:
        an array of two doubles with the first value equal the returned latitude and the second value equal to the returned longitude
